There have been cases where local people have actively resisted or fought against modern influences on their traditional practices and festivals. For some, there is a sense of importance and pride in their cultural heritage, which they fear may be lost or diluted due to the influence of modernization.

For example, there have been cases where local communities have resisted the commercialization or modernization of their traditional practices and festivals. In some cases, this has involved boycotting or protesting against the introduction of new elements or activities that they feel do not align with the original meaning and significance of the festival. 

At the same time, there are also local people who are actively embracing and adapting to the changes brought about by modernization. For some, this involves incorporating modern elements into traditional practices and festivals, such as using technology to enhance performances or adding new activities to attract a wider audience. 

Overall, there is a complex relationship between local people and the impacts of modernization on their traditional practices and festivals. While there is a desire to preserve and promote cultural heritage, there is also a recognition of the need to adapt and evolve to the rapidly changing modern world.
